The Truth About Food Sensitivity: How to Protect your GUT

Posted 8, June 2019 by
Dr. Dayana Deschamps - 0 min read

It is important to focus on cleaning our lifestyle as much as possible to live a vibrant and healthy life. However, we might eliminate all the bad stuff such as refined, processed, and sugary foods from our diet and still have digestive, hormonal, and mood problems.

You might be asking how this is possible, that means even the good stuff might be bad for you, let me explain this. The gassy, bloated, and fatigued feeling that you feel at least one hour after a meal for no apparent reason is the first indication. However, there are many more such as experiencing a sudden sadness, depression, and nose or rectal itching that last for days after consuming such meals. All these symptoms might cause a frequent visit to multiple practitioners with no results. The symptoms can vary, making it impossible for you to understand.

If you have any of the above symptoms, you might have a food sensitivity. Keep reading, it’s going to get good at the end.

In food sensitivity, the symptoms are so evasive that people have a hard time identifying the issue and might actually start to think it’s all in their head. Well, if that’s the case you are not alone, there are many people out there who are going through the same situation. But before getting ahead to give helpful hints and tips on how to find out about one’s food sensitivities; let’s take a short time to understand what food sensitivity is.

There are ways to find out and be healthy again, and this is what I am going to share with you today.

What is the Difference Between Food Allergy and Food Sensitivity?

Allergies come from different sources, it could be airborne, pollen, cat’s fur, or even food. It has been estimated that 1 in 3 individuals have an allergy of some sort and food allergy is one of the most common. Food allergies are pretty easy to spot though as dramatic reactions are activated immediately after ingesting the food in question.

Difference Between Actual Allergies and Food Sensitivity

Food Allergy Cause:

During a food allergy, the immune system is involved. The immune system releases markers against certain substances that it doesn’t trust. These classic markers are antibodies IgE. For example, people with peanut allergies can go into anaphylactic shock, a fatal condition that causes

  • trouble breathing,
  • severe drop in blood pressure,
  • dizziness,
  • itching,
  • swelling,
  • and hives.

However, not all allergies are IgE related. That’s what brings us to food intolerance commonly called food sensitivity.

Food Sensitivity Causes:

  • First of all, in food intolerance, the person might lack certain enzymes to digest a particular food; such as the case of people that are lactose intolerant. Or people that are celiac and have a reaction to gluten, a protein in wheat.
  • In certain cases, the person might have a sensitivity to the additives and coloring of certain foods. Other substances are amine in fermented foods, MSG, and salicylates in fruits, spices, and beverages among others.
  • It might be histamine toxicity. Such toxicity occurs in situations where tuna and mackerel are not refrigerated properly. The bacteria might contain higher levels of histamine that can provoke allergy-like symptoms similar to food poisoning.

In food sensitivity, IgG complex antibodies are involved. Food sensitivity is one of the subjects that people pay the least attention to, it doesn’t sound so scary after all, does it? Because of this people might suffer later from unwanted gut problems such as leaky gut syndrome and other gut disorders.

While food allergies cause an immediate response to foods, food sensitivity is delayed and might take up to 72 hours to show up. Research has shown that some cases might take up to a month to appear. In certain cases, food sensitivities can become chronic.

The Main Symptoms Caused by Food Sensitivities Involve:

  • digestive gastrointestinal complaints,
  • acid reflux,
  • skin issues such as pimples and even acne,
  • migraine and headache,
  • swollen joint and joint pain,
  • nasal discharge,
  • itchy eyes, nose, and/ or rectum,
  • mood problems, 
  • hormonal imbalance and PMS,
  • weight gain,
  • adrenal fatigue,
  • trouble sleeping and so on.

How to Know if You Have Food Sensitivity

The gut is like a second brain; many experts and practitioners are finding out how amazing the gut is, which makes it pretty comparable to the brain. From controlling your digestion to your mood, your gut does it all. That’s why we see that many individuals with gut issues end up with mood problems as it affects the feel-good hormones.

How Does it Affect you Emotionally?

One of the first things that we notice in people with food sensitivity is a stubborn persistence. Sometimes persistence occurs due to the person wanting to keep eating such foods thinking it’s healthy for them when actually the food in question is doing more harm than good. People with food sensitivity have a strong urge for food that can hurt them.

Craving certain foods

Craving from food sensitivity is very different from pica. Pica occurs mostly in pregnant women. It also differs from the craving caused by nutritional deficiencies where the body is craving food that contains the nutrients it needs. This specific type of craving is mainly like an addiction. The first thing that the person will notice is an irritable feeling until they eat the particular food they are craving for. While eating such food a feeling of euphoria and short-lived well-being may settle.

Difference between crave and food sensitivities

The same way an addict cannot stop the substance that he is addicted to, a person with a food sensitivity not only suffers from some or all the symptoms mentioned above, but they can also get emotional. They tend to get moody or irritable if the ingestion of such food does not take place. Most of the symptoms mentioned above start appearing after 72 hours of ingestion the culprit(s).

Because food sensitivity can provoke so many symptoms, it can be difficult to diagnose. So, once a practitioner suspects that food sensitivity is involved they might send for an IgG test to test for the protein in the food.

Food Allergy Tests in Conventional Medicine

1. The Pricking Test

Usually done by allergists, a small drop of the substance is placed on the patient’s arm or back then pricked with a special needle to allow the absorption of the allergen. Once reaction occurs then the allergist determines whether the person is sensitive to such food.

2. Blood Test

An allergen is mixed with the patient’s blood sample, causing the immune system to make antibodies called IgE. The amount of IgE can help an allergist determine whether a person is allergic to such food. This test while accurate only involves some allergens, not all.

3. An Oral Food Allergy Test

At timed intervals, the allergist gives a high amount of the food in question to the patient. Severe reactions can occur that will help determine whether the person is allergic to such food. It must be noted that in many places the Oral Food Allergy Test may not be available.

Best Alternative Way to Check Your Food Sensitivities

Alternative holistic practitioners may use muscle testing and hair testing. A well as the IGg blood test or immunoglobulin test usually recommended by Naturopath. It helps figure the food an individual is sensitive to, so it can be removed from their diet. A protocol is put in place to help rebuild the gut lining.

Do it Yourself

However, if you don’t have access to the listed tests, there are ways that you can test yourself at home.

• The Pulse Test

Being sensitive to food can cause an increased pulse rate immediately after eating such foods. This test can be done in the comfort of your house.

Sit and wait for your pulse to be rested, then chew a piece of the food that you want to test and wait for 30 seconds (don’t swallow). Test your pulse again for one full minute. Do not swallow the food, just spit it out. Write down the name of the tested food and your pulse result. Rinse your mouth properly and repeat the same process for the rest of the food you want to test. If your pulse rises 6 points or higher, then you’re likely sensitive or allergic to the food. If your pulse rises lower than 6 points or did not rise at all, then you probably don’t have a sensitivity or allergy to that food.

• The Blood Pressure Check

The blood pressure check is another way to find about food sensitivity, it is not costly as all you need is a blood pressure machine.

• An Elimination Diet

This is one of the most effective ways you can test your sensitivities. You do this test by eliminating the foods you suspect might be causing harm one by one and reintroducing them back to your diet (I have outlined the simplest way to do it in my eBook here). 

How to Fix the Problem?

You can fix this problem by avoiding any suspected substance or food that might be causing your food allergies. The most common foods to watch for are:

  • Food additives

  • Wheat and milk products

  • Soy products

  • Legumes

  • Corn

  • Citrus fruits

  • Caffeine

  • Chocolate

  • Nightshades such as tomatoes

  • Paprika

  • Red pepper

  • Potatoes

  • Eggplant

  • Cayenne

  • Chili and tobacco

  • Pineapple

  • Bee pollen

  • Shellfish

It is important to avoid such foods and support the gut with a healing program. That can help lower inflammation through diet and stress management.

Supplements to Protect the Gut Lining:

  • Probiotics

  • Digestive enzymes

  • L glutamine

  • Slippery elm

  • Okra powder

Beneficial Food

Bone broth is also beneficial as it contains lots of amino acids and collagen to assist in the healing process.

Essential Oils

Oregano oil is reported to help alleviate allergies. It can be diluted with a carrier oil used as an essential oil to apply to the Vital Flex points/Chakras. It can also be used orally and helps with various issues such as inflammation, digestive problems, and bacterial infection. It also acts as a liver protectant.

Last Thought

Whether you choose to try the conventional or alternative way, always remember that you need a plan. For busy people who are going to do an elimination diet, remember to remove refined, processed, and start a plan. 

Caution

You should never inhale oregano oil directly as it irritates the nasal passages. If you are on any medication or if you suffer any life-threatening condition you should consult with your healthcare provider before attempting anything on your own. This article is not a diagnosis of any diseases but rather an informational tool to help readers.
